name: Naz Deravian
bio: Author of Bottom of the Pot: Persian Recipes and Stories @flatiron_books Contributor @nytcooking #bottomofthepotthecookbook Los Angeles - Vancouver

social_posts.post_text:
When my family and I first left Iran for Italy, in those early days of displacement, we found comfort in the company of a few other Iranian families, who like us, were in search of a new home. Unsure if any other country would take us in; unsure if the privilege of a new life and freedom was in the cards for us, we sought solace in each other’s company.

My dear friend Sareh @thewritersway and her family made the journey from Tehran, to Rome, to Vancouver with us. Our lives; our triumphs; our struggles; and ultimately our forever search for “home” are stories I have shared in my book, Bottom of the Pot. 

I’m incredibly proud to share that Sareh’s beautiful book of poetry, Pistachios in my Pocket, which tells a poignant tale of Iran, family, revolution, home, and all that has been lost and found, launches today. It has been named by @the.nationalpost and @thevancouversun as one of the best holiday books to give and receive.

Congratulations, Sareh joon. You make us all proud, and I can’t wait for everyone to find their way to your beautiful words. And congratulations to my dear friend Sophie @thinkingship who worked as editor on the book. ❤️

Pistachios in my Pocket available at all book sellers.

Quick solo breakfast. Nourishment to see me through the day. This was my quick solo lunch yesterday, and breakfast today. I roasted a big batch of turmeric tofu, sweet potatoes and kale. Cafe latte on the side. Breakfast, lunch or dinner. And yes, that’s a ketchup/mustard swirl on the side.

THE WOMEN OF IRAN are TIME’s 2022 Heroes of The Year. 
 
Our heroes. The world’s heroes. Until freedom. 

#mahsaamini

THIS is the Iran news that should be shared and amplified today. 

Mohsen Shekari, 23 years old, is the first protester to be summarily executed by hanging. He was arrested in September and charged with “waging war against god” in a sham trial. His family was told to keep quiet and he would be released. He was executed this morning without their previous knowledge. His family is unable to retrieve his body. 

As horrific as this sounds, it’s nothing new. The Islamic Republic has a long history of mass executions. Despite the many narratives and distractions spun about executions, we knew this was going to happen. As are many more . Including children. 

The life of activist rapper Saman Yassin is in imminent danger (slide 2). Just today his execution order was announced. Do not be fooled. They will go through with it. 

It’s easy to feel paralyzed by all this horrid news (see slide 3). It’s easy to feel helpless. What can be done? Keep taking about it. Shine the light on it. Share. Share. Share. If you “liked” and shared the Time cover story yesterday, it’s SO MUCH MORE important to
share and amplify this news today. 

This is the Iran news that needs your attention today. Please do not look away. 

#mohsenshekari #samanyassin #mahsaamini

Early this morning, a second Iranian protester was summarily executed by hanging by the Islamic Republic. His name is Majidreza Rahnavard. Majidreza was 23-years-old. He was a champion wrestler. He had his whole life ahead of him. He loved and was loved. 

Yesterday, Majidreza’s mother was able to visit him, but neither was informed that the death sentence was to be carried out. They did not know he would be executed in a matter of hours.

Officials called Majidreza’s family at 7AM this morning, and told them to go to Behesht-e Reza Cemetery, plot 66. “We've executed your child and we buried him there,” they told his family.

The depravity and the cruelty is a part of their psychological warfare. But if they think that the onslaught of devastation and heartbreak, brought on by their barbaric crimes, will render us silent - they are gravely mistaken. If they think that we'll simply crawl in a corner and wither away in our sorrow - they are gravely mistaken. We will only get louder. We will only get more resolute in making sure our voices reach every corner of this world. And that they are brought to justice for over 43 years of crimes against humanity. 

Until freedom.
#StopExecutionsInIran
#majidrezarahnavard
#mahsaamini

My latest for @nytcooking - lamb shish kebabs. You can prepare them on the grill, oven or stovetop. Throw on some veggies, warm up bread and you’re set. Hope you make them and hope you enjoy! 

Big thank you to my always wonderful editor @tanyasic . Lovely photo and styling: @dmalosh and @simoncooks . Recipe link in bio.

The longest and darkest night of the year is upon us. Shab-e Yalda - the Iranian celebration of the winter solstice marking the triumph of light over darkness. 

Pomegranates on Yalda night symbolize the crimson hue of a new dawn - the rising sun. 

Tonight, with our hearts full of fire, rage, grief, determination, love, and hope, I will crack open a pomegranate. I will gather around the table with family and recount the story of Yalda. We will read the poetry of Hafez. We will be reminded of how these thousands years old traditions - celebrating light, hope, and freedom - have persisted despite the oppressors efforts to keep the world in darkness and pain. 

We will see this long and dark night through and welcome back the light. In honor of all the innocent lives lost in Iran; in honor of all the lives fighting for their freedom in the prisons; in honor of all the grieving families; in honor of the hopes and dreams of the youth; in honor of our elders; in honor of freedom; in honor of Iran. In honor of Woman Life Freedom. 

I invite you to join us tonight. Light a candle, crack open a pomegranate, and speak of the brave fight for freedom in Iran. Speak of Iran. 

Until freedom. Until freedom. Until freedom. 

#mahsaamini
Stand with the people of Iran. Share your support and solidarity on your own pages. #stopexecutionsiniran #mahsaamini #womanlifefreedom #freeiran

Last Nowruz, I had lofty plans to replant my hyacinth in hopes of placing them on the Haft Seen again this year. I do not have a green thumb. At all. 

I did some research and you had to place the bulb in a paper bag and hide it in a dark place, plus ten more steps that I knew I would not follow. I gave up on the hyacinth and put it outside with the intention of throwing it in the compost bin. And then I completely forgot about it. It was tucked away. Out of sight. 

Today, something bright pink caught my eye. I looked around the corner and there they were. Ten months went by and they endured the dry, hot, desolate Los Angeles summer. Ten months went by and all they had was each other. 

They survived the wind and rainstorms of the past two weeks. The one on the left was actually on its side. Knocked over by the elements. 

Today I gasped in awe. Today I smiled. Today I peeked around the corner, and it took my breath away. 

Now. What should I do? The rains are done. Who knows when they’ll visit again. Should I bring them inside? Should I dote on them? Or, should I just let them be. Let them be. Just let them be.

For my latest in @nytcooking, I had the pleasure of speaking to @andreanguyen88 @spicespoon @karla_tv @rosettacostantino about the utensil that is indispensable and loved in their kitchens. I look forward to adding these utensils to my own kitchen. (The nonna knives already hold a dear and permanent place in my kitchen drawer - Iranians, I know you get it!) .
.
Big thanks, as always, to my editors @tanyasic and @wonderdj . Link in bio.

This cozy bean, rice and dill soup is on rotation in our house. I made it last night with pantry staples and it comes together very quickly. You can use fresh dill, but I typically end up using dried dill. It’s just as good. I recommend having dried dill on hand for these last minute meals. My latest for @nytcooking . Lovely photo and styling @bobbilinstudio @eugenejho . Recipe link in bio.

I’m happy to be back (virtually) @civickitchensf on Sunday February 12, 3-5PM PT. We’ll be preparing khoresh karafs (celery stew), Iranian-style rice with tahdig (of course) and all the sides. This stew is perfect for this time of year and a family favorite. Also a fantastic way to use up a whole head of celery.

This class was originally scheduled in the fall but we had to cancel due to illness. There are only a couple of spots left. Hope you can join us virtually! Save your spot at civickitchensf.com Link also in bio.

Last week, I had the pleasure of working with @stanfordiranianstudies students. Our class focused on yogurt and its place in Iranian cuisine and at the Iranian table. I love working with these students who are so curious and excited to learn about our food and culture. This is a fantastic program, and particularly necessary these days to open up and continue the discussion about Iran. Thank you for having me @stanfordiranianstudies .

Shervin Hajipour is nominated for a Grammy this Sunday for his song Baraye: “Best Song For Social Change.” This song spoke of our collective hearts and became the anthem for all the brave freedom fighters of Iran. 44 years of anguish, 44 stolen years, poured out in this one song. Listen to it again. For a free Iran. For Zan Zendegi Azadi. 
#mahsaamini  #womanlifefreedom

In honor and memory of my cousin Fariborz. In honor of his loved ones who could not be with him in Iran. Yet another cruel result of the past 44 years. Saying goodbye from half a world away. Not being able to hold our loved ones hand. 
In honor and memory of all grieving families in Iran and abroad.

Hope lives in the midst of light and shadow. 

Friends, we will once again sprout our LENTIL sabzeh together for Nowruz. I hope you can join us on this journey to welcome new life; new beginnings; hope; resilience and peace. 

This year, we will begin the process on Monday March 6. All you need to start is 1 cup of green or brown lentils, a bowl and water. 

Please note: we are growing lentil sprouts NOT wheat (gandom) sabzeh. I will share more details as we get closer. 

#botpsabzeh2023

I’m happy to be back @civickitchensf for this virtual aash-e reshteh class. Aash is the foundation of Iranian cuisine and aash-e reshteh holds a special and symbolic place at the sofreh, especially around Nowruz. As we prepare the aash, we will discuss the history, symbolism and importance of aash in Iranian cuisine. 

This class takes place on the Sunday before Chaharshanbeh Suri, a perfect opportunity to make a big pot of aash and share it Tuesday night for Chaharshanbeh Suri. Hope you can join us. 

Sign up link in bio.

I wrote this back in 2014, in the early days of my blog. This word, this promise of azadi - freedom, is an unopened gift we’ve been carrying around in our hearts for our entire lives. 

It’s a long lost friend; it’s a friend we have yet to meet. It’s always close by; it lives half a world away. But sooner or later it will reveal itself. And when it does we will be ready to welcome it with open arms; open hearts; eyes full of tears; voices full of laughter. We are ready for you, azadi. 

This year, like the past thirteen years, Luna’s azadi bookmark will take its place on our haft seen table. 

Because it’s important. 

#womanlifefreedom #زن_زندگی_آزادی

Dear friends, we will begin sprouting our Nowruz sabzeh TOMORROW MONDAY MARCH 6. Nowruz means “new day” in Persian and sabzeh symbolizes new life and hope. Hope, peace, and freedom. 
🌱
I have to be honest, I’ve been struggling with whether I can do this this year. Our hearts and minds are continually with the people of Iran. The news is bleak. But then, I’m reminded that it’s exactly these rituals that root us, and give us a glimmer of hope and light amid the darkness. 
🌱
Nowruz is the celebration of the vernal equinox; a celebration of the earth’s natural cycles; a celebration of life and new beginnings. We will grow our sabzeh together with these sentiments front and center. And just like every other year, I invite everyone to join us, Iranians and non-Iranians. Nowruz and all that it symbolizes is universal. Peace, freedom, and hope. 
🌱
So, here’s what you need: 1 cup of regular brown or green lentils, a very thin kitchen towel or thin flour sack (that you don’t mind getting stained), or paper towels; a wide rimmed dish or pie plate; a spray bottle; sunlight (hopefully), and all the love and patience you can muster. 
🌱
It will take about 14 days for the sabzeh to grow just in time for Nowruz on Monday March 20 at 2:24PT. I’ll post every day and walk us through every step, and answer all your questions, as best as I can. It’s ok if you join a few days late. You can follow along #botpsabzeh2023 and catch up. Please share your progress with us too! 
🌱
Who’s joining us? Comment below and let us know where you’re joining from, and let’s support each other and welcome new life and hope together. This is also a great project for kids. I know we already have a few school teachers following along and sprouting sabzeh with their students. I can’t think of a better way to welcome spring and to speak of Iran with young people. 🌱

SABZEH DAY 1: Place 1 cup lentils in a large bowl. Look through the lentils and pick out any little stones, or shriveled up or broken lentils. Add cold water to the lentils, to cover at least by 2 inches. Do not cover the bowl; set aside to soak. Don’t place in direct sun. Try to keep away from cats! For the next 3 days we’ll be changing the water daily. I’ll post every day to remind us. I’m here to answer any questions! #botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

SABZEH DAY 2: Very gently tip out the old water and cover the lentils again with plenty of fresh cold water and set aside to soak. No need to cover the bowl. Keep away from direct sunlight. You can tip the old water out at your sink but a great tip I learned from @kcrwevan is that plants benefit from the soaking liquid of legumes. So if possible, feed you plants with the old sabzeh water. 
🌱
It’s not too late to start! Start with Day 1 and follow along. (Reminder we are sprouting lentils, not wheat.) #botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

SABZEH DAY 3: Just like yesterday, tip out the old water, refill with plenty of fresh cold water and set aside to soak. If you look closely you might see the skin cracking, and the lentils splitting, or even a few tiny tiny sprouts. And if you don’t IT’S OKAY. No need to panic. They’ll reveal themselves when they’re ready. And it’s still not too late to join us! Begin with day 1 and follow along. Remember, we want the sabzeh to last 12 days AFTER ringing in the new year on March 20. #botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh 🌱

On this International Women’s Day, I’d like to wish my maman, Monir Taha, a very happy birthday. 

Maman jaan, thank you for your wisdom, your words, your honesty, your music, your poetry, your truth, your strength, your pragmatism, your sense of humor, your joyful laughter. 

Thank you for showing us what standing up to injustice means. Thank you for teaching me what love for country and culture means. Your hope, your dream for a free and democratic Iran lives. It lives. 

This was Monir’s first magazine cover when she was about twenty-years-old. 

Happy birthday. ❤️

Beyond excited on this international Women’s Day to release this podcast episode in conversation with Naz Deravian, author of Bottom of the Pot, about the poem “meegan ké jangé jangé” by her mother, the poet Monir Taha.

Monir is recognized as the first female lyricist in Iran, and was working, writing lyrics to many famous songs we all know and love (by musicians like Banan, Shajarian, Sattar, Marzieh, and many others) from a very young age in Iran. She’s a wonderful example of the strength and prominence of women in Iran prior to the revolution. Naz gives us context into Monir’s childhood and how she became a lyricist and poet. 

The particular poem we talked about, meegan ké jangé jangé, meaning “they say it’s war, it’s war”, was written after Monir and her family emigrated from Iran, and during the Iran Iraq war. However, the themes of the poem are eerily and sadly relevant to what we are going through today. It is a poem about the coming of spring, and the happiness of birth and renewal, but of the juxtaposition of that truth with the fact that Iran is in a state of crisis.

I loved hearing Naz talk about this poem, which she also recited on @padmalakshmi ‘s excellent show Taste the Nation, and about how it can express how we, those of us in the diaspora, can reconcile the natural joy we feel for the coming of spring with the inherent sadness of what’s happening to our country.

It was so touching to hear @bottomofthepot honor her mother with this episode. You can hear her reciting the poem in its entirety by swiping right on the image above.

Also, in addition to it being international woman’s day, it’s also Monir’s birthday, so let’s all honor her by listening to this wonderful interview wherever you get your podcasts (search for Chai and Conversation on Spotify) and listening to the poem.

SABZEH DAY 4: Mr Husband is our special
guest today. If you followed last year, you’ll remember that Mr Husband was in charge of the sabzeh for the first week. And he’s back! 
🌱
Your lentils should be splitting a little and some skin might be slipping off. If you look closely you’ll also see very tiny sprouts poking through. If you don’t, it’s ok (soak them one more day and join from here tomorrow). 
🌱
Place a flour sack, or a cheese cloth, or a very thin kitchen towel that you don’t mind staining, over a large platter (I’m using the pie plate that my sabzeh will sprout on). Gently drain the lentils (yes, you can use a colander to drain) and spread them on top of the towel. They DON’T have to be spread out in a single layer. They’re fine on top of each other. Cover the top of the lentils with the other half of the towel or place a paper towel on top of the lentils to cover. 
🌱
Spray or sprinkle the lentils with water 3 to 4 times a day to keep them damp until they sprout. The cloth shouldn’t be dry. Place the lentils in a light filled room. But not in direct sunlight. We’ll be doing this for the next couple of days, depending on how quickly your lentils sprout. 
🌱
A couple of things to keep in mind: You want the lentils and the cloth underneath to remain nice and damp, BUT you don’t want the lentils to be swimming in water. But you also don’t want the lentils to dry out. It’s a balancing act. 
🌱
If it’s particularly cold where you live, you might want to keep the lentils close to a heat source so they sprout faster, but without drying them out.
🌱
Keep in mind that Nowruz begins on March 20th, and optimally we want our sabzeh to last for 13 days thereafter. So, if it’s particularly hot where you live and you want to slow down the growth of your sabzeh, keep it in a cooler light-filled spot.
🌱
Eventually, once the lentils sprout, the cloth under the sabzeh will be removed and the lentils will get transferred to the 
🌱
If you’re just joining us - welcome! It’s not too late to start! Follow along on #botpsabzeh2023 and start with Day 1.  #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

SABZEH DAY 5: Take a peek under the cloth. Can you see tiny little sprouts popping up? Signs of life and hope. Life and hope. 
🌱
Keep your sabzeh covered; keep spraying or sprinkling with water a few times a day to keep damp and place in a light-filled room (if possible). Just like yesterday. 
🌱
It’s ok if you don’t see any tiny sprouts yet. Keep at it. They’ll reveal themselves when they’re ready. 
🌱
You still have time to join us. Begin with Day 1 and follow along #botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

SABZEH DAY 6: You should be seeing little shoots. And if you’re not don’t worry - hang in there!
🌱
Gently transfer the lentils from the cloth to a dish you want to display your sabzeh. I’m using the same pie plate and another smaller dish. You can use just one pie plate or similar dish. The lentils should be on top of each other, DON’T spread them in a single layer. Now cover the lentils with the same cloth and spray a few times a day to keep the cloth nice and damp. 
🌱
We’ll keep doing this for the next 2 to 3 days until we see green shoots. There’s still time to join us. Yes, really! Follow along on #botpsabzeh2023 begin on Day 1. #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

SABZEH DAY 7: Take a peek under the cloth. See any tiny green shoots? That’s what we’re looking for. Ours isn’t quite there. But looks like it might be ready to be unveiled tomorrow! It really seems like magic every time. Keep your sabzeh covered; keep spraying with water to keep the cloth wet; place in a light-filled spot. 
🌱
If where you live is cold, keep the sabzeh away from drafts and place it in a warm spot (next to a heat source, in the kitchen etc). 
🌱
Take a peek under the cloth. See any tiny green shoots? That’s what we’re looking for. Ours isn’t quite there. But looks like it might be ready to be unveiled tomorrow! It really seems like magic every time. 
🌱
It’s still not too late join! Start on Day 1 and follow along #botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

SABZEH DAY 8: Where there is light there is hope. 
🌱
Do you see any tiny green shoots? If you do, remove the cloth and start chasing the light! Keep sprinkling or spraying with water, place in a warm spot and wherever there’s sunlight or plenty of light.
🌱
If too much water gathers at the bottom of your dish just gently tip some out. If you see any mold, carefully remove and water less! If your sabzeh isn’t quite there yet, don’t worry. Keep it covered and see where you’re at later today or tomorrow. At this point it’ll be more of a personal sabzeh journey. 
🌱
It’s absolutely fine if we’re not all at the same sabzeh stage. Keep watering and start chasing the light. 
#botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

I’m happy to have curated a Nowruz menu for @epicurious . I’m thrilled to fill this Nowruz table with a few recipes from a number of beautiful new Iranian cookbooks: Pomegranates & Artichokes by Saghar Setareh @labnoon ; Yogurt and Whey by Homa Dashtaki @whitemoustacheyogurt ; Maman and Me by @royashariat and Gita Sadeh; well as a couple of lovely recipes by @andybaraghani. 

There’s no such thing as needing only one Iranian cookbook or recipe. We all have unique stories to tell and each of these books and recipes shines on its own. Let’s fill our shelves with as many Iranian stories as possible. Thank you all for sharing your recipes with me. 

Big thanks to @ahezel , it was a pleasure working on this with you. 

Link to the piece in my bio.

SABZEH DAY 9: It’s a rainy and dark day here in Los Angeles. It’s funny, because this year I haven’t been as worried about my sabzeh. Bigger worries and concerns occupy my thoughts. And yet, and yet, and yet. My sabzeh has decided to show me the path. A moment of respite and hope. 
🌱
Keep watering well, but make sure to very carefully tip out any excess water that pools at the bottom of the platter to avoid any mold. Chase the light! Where the sun goes so does our sabzeh (at a safe distance from the cats) - but take care not to let it dry out in too much sun. Remember it’s a balance of water and light. 
🌱
No filters on these photos so you can see exactly where our sabzeh is at. #botpsabzeh2023 #spring #nowruz #sabzeh

SABZEH DAY 10: This process is different every year. It keeps you guessing; it keeps you fretting; it tests your patience; it keeps you hopeful; it keeps you in awe of the most simple act of witnessing nature come back to life. 
🌱
My sabzeh has sprouted quite nicely and quickly this year. The sprouts themselves are much more light and delicate. As if they don’t have a care in the world; as if they’ve shed all their worries; as if nothing can keep them from reaching for the light. Not my somewhat lack of attention to them, and not the continuous Los Angeles rains. 
🌱
Regardless of where your sabzeh is at, keep going. Keep watering and keep chasing the light. Any light, even if it’s a muted rainstorm light. 
🌱
A reminder that we want our sabzeh to thrive for 13 days AFTER welcoming the new year on Monday March 20 at 2:24PM PT. Keep going. 
#botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #sabzeh #spring

Watering the sabzeh: This is how I like to water the sabzeh so it’s nice and hydrated (no shriveled up dry lentils) but also careful so it doesn’t get moldy. Too much water: mold and smelly. Not enough water: dry and shriveled up. Balance. #botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

SABZEH DAY 11: As we approach A New Day, Nowruz, excitement and anticipation fills the air. This year it’s different. It’s different for me and for many other friends and family I’ve talked to. 
🌱
This year, with every passing day towards spring, it feels like my boghz, the lump in my throat, is that much closer to bursting. Bursting for our beautiful country, our beautiful people, our beautiful culture. 
🌱
But we press on. The best that we each can. In our own way. 
🌱
If your sabzeh is struggling, keep nurturing it - it will get there in its own time. We all live in different climates. And this is nature at work. It will do as it does. Keep going. 
🌱
This song by Shahram Nazeri is one of my favorites. It’s one that I turn to over and over again for inspiration and energy. Hope it gives you a lift, wherever you are. 
🌱
Keep going. Keep watering. Keep chasing the light. Even if it’s just a sliver of light. Keep going. 
🌱
#botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

SABZEH DAY 12: Any other year, I’d be fretting right now that my sabzeh sprouted too quickly. It’s about 2 to 3 days ahead of where I’d optimally like it be for March 20. We want the sabzeh to keep thriving 13 days after ringing in the new year. 
🌱
But none of this really matters. For whatever reason my sabzeh was eager to reveal itself early this year. Despite the LA rains and cold. Despite my less than typical attention and care for it. Despite our heavy hearts and preoccupied minds. This is what Nowruz is about. Nature carries on at its own whim and fancy. 
🌱
If your sabzeh is not growing as quickly as you would like, if it’s not as green as you would like, if it’s not as full, don’t give up on it.
🌱
If your lentils look dry and shriveled, water more. If you’re worried about mold and smell, drain well and water less. Keep chasing the light. Use artificial light if you can. If your sabzeh has given you the gift of even one little green shoot, don’t give up on it. Keep going. 
🌱
And in the end, if it just doesn’t sprout this year, be kind to it and yourself. Iranian markets have plenty of sabzeh you can pick up. Or hit up your local natural food store or juice bar and ask for a square of their wheat grass. Or simply use a green plant. Or draw a picture of sabzeh and use that. It all is valid and works. 
🌱
Our sabzeh is on a high shelf out of reach of the cats. Keep going. Keep watering. Keep chasing the light. #botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #sabzeh #spring

SABZEH DAY 13: A new day is just around the corner and the sun is back out in LA. 
🌱
While it’s true that sabzeh benefits from a warm sunny climate, keep in mind that this tradition weaves through the peaks of the Alborz Mountains, to the ports of the PERSIAN GULF and beyond. Sabzeh sprouts in the cold and snowy climes of Tabriz, as it does in the more dry climes of Sistan Baluchestan. From Khorasan Provinces to Kurdistan, these sprouts grow. 
🌱
Keep watering and keep chasing the light, friends. 
#botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

SABZEH DAY 14: I appreciate you all so much for joining me and my family on this sabzeh journey, especially this year. Thank you for sharing your kind words, support, encouragement, frustrations at the sabzeh not sprouting fast enough, doubts, worries, and most importantly camaraderie. 
🌱
If your sabzeh hasn’t reached its full
potential - give it time, it will. If you’d prefer to place a fully grown sabzeh on your haft seen tomorrow, it’s perfectly fine to buy one. What’s most important is the process. Of going through this together. Together. Iranians and non-Iranians alike. 
🌱
Our sabzeh journey is far from over. Let me know if you have questions. I’m hoping my sabzeh thrives until seezdah bedar - the thirteenth day of Nowruz when we’ll return our sabzeh back to nature. 
🌱
Keep watering your sabzeh, as it needs it. If it’s fully grown it will need less water. And always keep reaching for the light and hope. 
🌱
#botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

A new day is upon us. Nowruz is here. So many of us share the same wish this year. Freedom for Iran. Freedom for the beautiful and courageous people of Iran. Better and brighter days are ahead. 
🌱
I had to travel this Nowruz, but Mr Husband and the girls made sure to set up the haft seen. In honor of new beginnings; kindness; our planet earth; peace; and freedom.
🌱
Happy Nowruz, friends. Wherever you are take a moment and welcome this new day. And please keep speaking of the people of Iran.

Thank you President and Dr Biden for honoring Nowruz yesterday and having me at the White House. It was a hopeful day and it was a pleasure to be your guest. May hope and the clarion call for new beginnings flourish this new year. 
🌱
Thank you all for your kind messages about my outfit. This outfit is my mom’s and it is over fifty-years-old. It was specifically made for her and the fabric depicts Khayyam’s Rubaiyat. Khayyam, the speaker of truth and the here and now. She has kept it mint condition and I hope to do the same for another fifty years. ❤️

In a special Nowruz edition of #passerbyrecipes, @bottomofthepot shares her take on Kuku Sabzi. ⁠
⁠
Image 2 — @ericwolfinger

As millions of Iranians and others worldwide including those in Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Afghanistan, and parts of Turkey celebrate Nowruz - I took the opportunity to speak with two Iranian-American female chefs and cookbook authors to not just share with you a bit about this millenia-old tradition, what it means for Iranians and our culture, but to also introduce you to a a few staple (and easy to make) dishes that millions of Iranians cook during the 13-days of Nowruz.
Whilst I cook this quintessential Iranian meal: “Sabzi Polo Mahi”, I have an intimate chat with award-winning author, blogger, and actor Naz Deravian who highlights her own powerful immigrant journey from Iran to the US, what Nowruz means to her family, the colorful essays in her book “Bottom of the Pot: Persian Recipes and Stories” that illuminate the role of food in Iranian culture and its power in humanized storytelling as well as the bravery being displayed by Iranian protests.
At a momentous point in Iran’s modern history and a time of deep reflection, I wholeheartedly believe it’s more important than ever for Iranians (especially those in the diaspora) to honor our heritage and aim to build bridges among our communities and others in an effort to amplify how millions of Iranains share so much common-grounds, values, and aspirations with millions of others worldwide.
I hope you enjoy the first of this two part Nowruz series and learn a bit more about Iran and Iranian people.

Our sabzeh is hanging in there as we inch closer to the final few days of Nowruz. 
🌱
Sunday, April 2 is sizdah bedar, the 13th and last day of Nowruz. This is another day brimming with symbolism and hope. Always hope. 
🌱
The number 13 is considered unlucky (as it is in many cultures) and so, on the 13th day of Nowruz it’s considered a bad omen to be indoors. It’s also considered unlucky to keep your sabzeh indoors from this day on.
🌱
Pack a picnic, grab a blanket and your sabzeh, and head outdoors. Surround yourself with fresh air and nature. 
🌱. 
Traditionally, before you say goodbye to your sabzeh, you tie two blades of the sprouts together and make a wish for the new year. You can also tie blades of grass, if you don’t have a sabzeh. And then you remove the sabzeh from its container, and release it into a flowing body of water, like a stream or a river. From nature back to nature. 
🌱
If releasing your sabzeh into water is not an option, you can compost it or plant it. However you choose to discard your sabzeh just do it mindfully. From nature back to nature. 
🌱
And with hope. Always hope.

#botpsabzeh2023 #nowruz #spring #sabzeh

From nature back to nature. 
🌱
#botpsabzeh2023

It’s always a pleasure and a thrill to read @vonbremzen . Anya’s work is consistently scholarly (without being overbearing); historical with plenty of humor thrown in; her observations so thoughtful (and delicious) that they spark numerous conversations. National Dish is no exception. The global discussion of nationalism is very prevalent right now, and food has and continues to play a big part in it. Thank you Anya and @penguinrandomhouse for sharing this advanced copy with me. I can’t wait to talk to you more about this important and exciting topic. National Dish will be published June 20. “Who decides what makes a national cuisine?”

One-pot whole roasted chicken and rice is my latest for @nytcooking . This dish is fantastic to share with friends or as a cozy family meal. The chicken and rice cook together, with the rice absorbing the aromatic saffron and turmeric-stained juices of the chicken. Big thanks to @dmalosh for the lovely photo and @simoncooks for the mouthwatering styling, and as always my editor @tanyasic . Link to recipe in profile.

Breakfast, lunch or dinner, fried eggs and potatoes is a staple across many cuisines and ultimate comfort food in our house. Especially on busy week nights like tonight! Enjoy it as is, serve with a salad, or scoop up the perfect bite with some lavash. Hope you try it and let me know what you think! 
You can find the recipe @nytcooking and in profile. Beautiful photo and styling: @linda.xiao and @rebeccajurkevich .

All the recipes I write and share are first tested at our family table. And no one holds back with their honest opinion. My @nytcooking baked salmon and dill rice had unanimous approval, even among the most scrupulous taste buds. The sweet and slightly spicy salmon bakes directly on top of the dill rice, and it all comes together fairly quickly. Hope you try it and let me know what you think! .
Thank you @linda.xiao and @rebeccajurkevich for the lovely photo and styling. 
Recipe link in profile.

Another amazing virtual cooking class @civickitchensf . This time we prepared an Iranian-style brunch. Such a great and enthusiastic group. We prepared naan-e shirmal (milk bread) from scratch; sour cherry jam (also from scratch); nargesi (narcissus spinach eggs); Iranian-style tea; and all the sides. Happy early Father’s Day, friends.

Very excited to have a couple of our favorite no cook dishes featured in @nytcooking print (!!) today. Pick up a copy, there are so many great, easy, fun recipes for these hot hot days. Noon-o Paneer-o Sabzi gets the close up it deserves (thank you @lishsteiling for styling and @bryangardnerphotography for the 📸). Heading into the weekend with a few bright, nostalgic, fun and cozy American classics. My latest for @nytcooking . Tequila Sunrise; Pigs in a Blanket; American Chicken Alfredo. 

A big thank you to the entire team. My superb editors @margaux_laskey @melissaknific , fabulous tester @lisanicklin , and @christophertestani and @simoncooks for bringing the dishes to life so beautifully.

The Iranian singer, Mehdi Yarrahi, who released the powerful song “Your Scarf” in support of #womanlifefreedom , was arrested today. As we get closer to the one year anniversary of the killing of #mahsa_amini , Yarrahi has urged everyone to keep speaking of, writing, and honoring the victims. Please continue standing with the people of Iran. Please stand with #mehdi_yarrahi and the countless innocent people in detention.
#روسریتو #مهسا_امینی #زن_زندگی_آزادی

One year. Today marks the one year anniversary of the killing of Jina Mahsa Amini. The inscription on her gravestone reads: “Dearest Jina, you will not die. Your name will become a code.” A code. A rallying cry for freedom for the people of Iran. A name that broke the spell. Wherever you are today, please say her name. Say it quietly in your heart; yell it loudly from the rooftops. Today and every day we keep Jina’s family, and all the grieving families in our hearts. Say her name. Until freedom. 
#mahsaamini #womanlifefreedom
A chaotic kitchen is always a happy kitchen. (Except when you have to clean up!) Happy Monday.

I made the viral TikTok sensation “Marry Me Chicken” for @nytcooking . While I can’t attest to a proposal, I’m happy to report the entire family loved it. And we continue to hold each other up through the storm clouds and brighter days. 

Thank you to my patient and supportive editors @melissaknific @margaux_laskey , wonderful recipe tester @mymidlifespices , and the always amazing photo and styling team @dmalosh and @simoncooks .

Recipe @nytcooking and link in profile.

Last month marked Bottom of the Pot’s fifth birthday and eighth printing. I’m overwhelmed with gratitude for all your love and support. 

Five years ago I had no idea what to expect releasing a cookbook into the world. All I hoped was that my personal stories about Iran and Iranian food would resonate with a few people, and that maybe a couple of these dishes would find their way to your dinner tables. The response has been truly humbling. 

Bottom of the Pot would not exist without the incredible team, who are like family, behind it. I feel extremely fortunate to be surrounded by such talented and supportive professionals: To the entire team @flatiron_books , my editors @karalearota @willschwalbe @callmenyrb I have learned so much from you. The incredible photography, design and styling team @ericwolfinger @sowinsdesign Alma Espinola, @valerieaikmansmith @sandrastirsalot @connorthebruce The book continues to shine because of you. @_kimberlyescobar_  @barbarateszler for your friendship and always having my back and getting the word out. To all the  independent book sellers who are always rooting for authors, especially first time authors @kalnyc @nowservingla @omnivorebooks @booklarder @thebookjewel And to my super agents @stevetroha and @dadodd none of this would be without you. Thank you. ❤️

Much has happened in the past five years. This is but one story. One story about my childhood memories of Iran; immigration; and life in the diaspora. About all the saffron we carried with us, and all the  unspoken grief and loved ones we left behind. About moving forward, but always looking back, with a lump in our throats, for a home and a life left behind. Our stories continue. Seek them out. Cook from all the amazing Iranian cookbooks; read all the stories. 

Thank you for embracing this book and this one story. Thank you from the bottom of my pot.

Nazgol

Bay Area friends, I’m very happy to join my dear friend and talented chef, Hanif Sadr @komaajfood for an IN PERSON class @civickitchensf on Monday November 20, 2023 6-10 PM. 

The class will focus on Northern Iranian cuisine, and the foods and symbolism of Yalda (Iranian celebration of the winter solstice).

A very big thank you to Jen @civickitchensf for having us. Hope to see you there. Link to registration in bio.

A few weeks ago, I had the pleasure of teaching and cooking @civickitchensf with my dear friend chef Hanif Sadr @komaajfood . We prepared 7 dishes highlighting Northern Iranian cuisine and ingredients. The feast, featuring pomegranate-based dishes, was also in preparation for Yalda, the Iranian celebration of the winter solstice. What an uplifting and wonderful night. A very big thank you to everyone who attended on a busy Monday night, and to Jen and the whole crew @civickitchensf for having us. I hope to be back soon! 

Thank you @dr._pomegranate for the photos! 

I hope to share more about Yalda in the days to come. Comment below if you have any questions about how to prepare for Yalda.

Two years ago, I wrote about Yalda, the Iranian celebration of the winter solstice, and the longest and darkest night of the year, for @nytcooking .

“On Yalda, which falls on Dec. 21 this year…It is believed that, with the sun’s triumphant rise, our days will shine brighter and longer with hope and good will…All the food, the pomegranates in particular, serves as a joyful reminder that the re-emergence of the sun, light, hope and goodness is only but a night away.” 

You can read about Yalda and the symbolic foods associated with it (like Khoresh Morgh Naardooni (pomegranate chicken stew) in the link in my bio. 

Photo 1: @maxwhittaker 
Photo 2: @ryanliebe ; food stylist @bwashbu

We will celebrate the triumph of light over darkness together. We will see this dark and long night through together. We will welcome back the light together. Together. 

Happy Yalda to all. Here’s to brighter days ahead.
Author of Bottom of the Pot: Persian Recipes and Stories @flatiron_books Contributor @nytcooking #bottomofthepotthecookbook Los Angeles - Vancouver
